Synset.Definition: evoke a reaction, response, or emotion
Synset.Example: "this writer strikes a chord with young women"

Synset.Definition: elicit responses, such as objections, criticism, applause, etc.
Synset.Example: "The President's comments drew sharp criticism from the Republicans"
"The comedian drew a lot of laughter"

Synset.Definition: arouse unreasoning love or passion in and cause to behave in an irrational way
to cause a sharp emotional pain
Synset.Example: "The thought of her unhappiness pricked his conscience"

Synset.Definition: arouse or excite feelings and passions
Synset.Example: "The ostentatious way of living of the rich ignites the hatred of the poor"
"The refugees' fate stirred up compassion around the world"

Synset.Definition: work up into agitation or excitement
stir the feelings, emotions, or peace of

Synset.Example: "This movie usually arouses the male audience"

Synset.Definition: cause to be agitated, excited, or roused
Synset.Example: "The speaker charged up the crowd with his inflammatory remarks"
"The audience was jolted by the play"
"My boss was bubbling over with anger"

Synset.Definition: be in an agitated or excited state

Synset.Example: "The children were all psyched up after the movie"
"Don't let yourself be lulled into a false state of security"

Synset.Definition: become quiet or calm, especially after a state of agitation
Synset.Example: "After the fight both men need to cool off."
"It took a while after the baby was born for things to settle down again."

Synset.Definition: disturb in mind or make uneasy or cause to be worried or alarmed
Synset.Example: "She was rather perturbed by the news that her father was seriously ill"

Synset.Definition: derange mentally, throw out of mental balance; make insane
Synset.Example: "The death of his parents unbalanced him"
"quiet the dragons of worry and fear"
"She had to compose herself before she could reply to this terrible insult"

Synset.Definition: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
Synset.Example: "She managed to mollify the angry customer"

Synset.Definition: disturb the peace of mind of; afflict with mental agitation or distress
Synset.Example: "I cannot sleep--my daughter's health is worrying me"

Synset.Definition: worry or cause anxiety in a persistent way
cause to feel sure; give reassurance to
Synset.Example: "The airline tried to reassure the customers that the planes were safe"
"he retired from life when his wife died"

Synset.Definition: be worried, concerned, anxious, troubled, or uneasy
be in an agitated emotional state
seethe with deep anger or resentment
have an emotional or cognitive impact upon
Synset.Example: "This child impressed me as unusually mature"
"The event engraved itself into her memory"

Synset.Definition: render speechless, as by surprising or shocking
Synset.Example: "we were struck dumb by the candidate's announcement"
"This show zaps the viewers with some shocking scenes"

Synset.Definition: refer to or be relevant or familiar to

Synset.Example: "He was smitten with love for this young girl"

Synset.Definition: move or affect (a person's emotions or bodily feelings) deeply or sharply

Synset.Example: "The young chess player impressed her audience"

Synset.Definition: make a positive impression (on someone) beforehand

Synset.Example: "I was touched by your kind letter of sympathy"
"Her childish behavior really get to me"

Synset.Definition: undergo an emotional sensation or be in a particular state of mind

Synset.Example: "She inclines to the view that people should be allowed to express their religious beliefs"
"She could not recapture that feeling of happiness"
"He prides himself on making it into law school"

Synset.Definition: give expression or emotion to, in a stage or movie role

Synset.Example: "She resents being paid less than her co-workers"

Synset.Definition: cause to be bitter or resentful
gnaw into; make resentful or angry
bear a grudge; harbor ill feelings
dislike intensely; feel antipathy or aversion towards

Synset.Example: "He despises the people he has to work for"
"The professor scorns the students who don't catch on immediately"

Synset.Definition: have a great affection or liking for
Synset.Example: "She loves her boss and works hard for him"

Synset.Definition: be enamored or in love with
fall in love with; become infatuated with
Synset.Example: "She fell for the man from Brazil"

Synset.Definition: to remain emotionally or intellectually attached
Synset.Example: "He clings to the idea that she might still love him."

Synset.Definition: be fond of; be attached to
have a fancy or particular liking or desire for
Synset.Example: "She fancied a necklace that she had seen in the jeweler's window"

Synset.Definition: have or feel a dislike or distaste for
shower with love; show excessive affection for
have affection for; feel tenderness for
feel less enamoured of something or somebody
love unquestioningly and uncritically or to excess; venerate as an idol
regard with feelings of respect and reverence; consider hallowed or exalted or be in awe of

Synset.Example: "The stranger who hangs around the building frightens me"

Synset.Definition: subdue, restrain, or overcome by affecting with a feeling of awe; frighten (as with threats)
be afraid or scared of; be frightened of

Synset.Example: "I fear the results of the final exams"

Synset.Definition: be sorry; used to introduce an unpleasant statement
Synset.Example: "I fear I won't make it to your wedding party"

Synset.Definition: be afraid or feel anxious or apprehensive about a possible or probable situation or event

Synset.Example: "Her big brother always bullied her when she was young"

Synset.Definition: rule or exercise power over (somebody) in a cruel and autocratic manner
cause sudden fear in or fill with sudden panic
Synset.Example: "The mere thought of an isolation cell panicked the prisoners"

Synset.Definition: be overcome by a sudden fear
Synset.Example: "The students panicked when told that final exams were less than a week away"

Synset.Definition: fill with apprehension or alarm; cause to be unpleasantly surprised
Synset.Example: "I was horrified at the thought of being late for my interview"
"The news of the executions horrified us"
"The news of the bombing shocked her"

Synset.Definition: engage or engross the interest or attention of beforehand or occupy urgently or obsessively
Synset.Example: "The matter preoccupies her completely--she cannot think of anything else"
"The idea of his failure prepossesses him"
"When he saw the accident, he freaked out"
"When she heard that she had not passed the exam, she lost it completely"
"She dissolved into tears when she heard that she had lost all her savings in the pyramid scheme"

Synset.Definition: be brought to or as if to the point of death by an intense emotion such as embarrassment, amusement, or shame
Synset.Example: "I was dying with embarrassment when my little lie was discovered"
"We almost died laughing during the show"

Synset.Definition: languish as with love or desire
force out or release suddenly and often violently something pent up
cause to lose courage; to be daunted; to be scared away

Synset.Example: "She bridled at his suggestion to elope"

Synset.Definition: cause to become violent or angry
Synset.Example: "Riots combusted Pakistan after the U.S. air attacks on Afghanistan"
"It galls me that we lost the suit"
"her indifference to his amorous advances really steamed the young man"
"He will raise the roof when he hears this"

Synset.Definition: drive up the wall; go on someone's nerves
cause to go crazy; cause to lose one's mind
cause annoyance in; disturb, especially by minor irritations
Synset.Example: "Mosquitoes buzzing in my ear really bothers me"
"It irritates me that she never closes the door after she leaves"
"He was chafing at her suggestion that he stay at home while she went on a vacation"

Synset.Definition: cause to be annoyed, irritated, or resentful
cause to feel resentment or indignation

Synset.Example: "He is known to harry his staff when he is overworked"

Synset.Definition: make (someone) self-conscious and as a result unable to act naturally
Synset.ILIDefinition: make (someone) self-conscious and as a result unable to act naturally
Synset.Example: "his father's cold and distant demeanor inhibited him emotionally"

Synset.Definition: cause to be nervous or upset

Synset.Example: "This play is going to ruffle some people"
"She has a way of ruffling feathers among her colleagues"
"The constant attention of the young man confused her"

Synset.Definition: fill with anxiety, dread, dismay, or confusion
Synset.Example: "After the terrorist attack, people look consternated"

Synset.Definition: make confused or perplexed or puzzled

Synset.Example: "The mere thought of her bothered him and made his heart beat faster"

Synset.Definition: draw someone's attention away from something
be flustered; behave in a confused manner
cause to be embarrassed; cause to feel self-conscious

Synset.Example: "The republic soon discountenanced its few friends"

Synset.Definition: cause emotional anguish or make miserable
Synset.Example: "It pains me to see my children not being taught well in school"

Synset.Definition: cause deep emotional pain and grief to somebody
Synset.Example: "The young man broke the girl's heart when he told her was going to marry her best friend"
"She hurt me when she did not include me among her guests"

Synset.Definition: deeply hurt the feelings of; distress
cause an emotional pain, as if by stinging

Synset.Example: "don't fuss too much over the grandchildren--they are quite big now"
"He lied and did not even scruple about it"
"Every time her husband gets drunk, she suffers"

Synset.Definition: suffer the loss of a person through death or removal
Synset.Example: "She lost her husband in the war"
"The couple that wanted to adopt the child lost her when the biological parents claimed her"

Synset.Definition: get very angry and fly into a rage
Synset.Example: "The professor combusted when the student didn't know the answer to a very elementary question"

Synset.Definition: put into a rage; make violently angry

Synset.Example: "Rage against the dying of the light!"

Synset.Definition: be in a state of uncontrolled anger
feel sudden intense sensation or emotion
Synset.Example: "he was thrilled by the speed and the roar of the engine"

Synset.Definition: feel remorse for; feel sorry for; be contrite about
turn away from sin or do penitence
feel sad about the loss or absence of
observe the customs of mourning after the death of a loved one

Synset.Example: "she was afflicted by the death of her parents"
"The news of her child's illness distressed the mother"

Synset.Definition: cause to feel distressed or worried
Synset.Example: "She was besieged by so many problems that she got discouraged"
"I've been sorely tried by these students"

Synset.Definition: fail to meet the hopes or expectations of
Synset.Example: "Her boyfriend let her down when he did not propose marriage"

Synset.Definition: disappoint, prove undependable to; abandon, forsake
Synset.Example: "His sense of smell failed him this time"
"His children failed him in the crisis"
"The teachers were hamstrung by the overly rigid schedules"

Synset.Definition: cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of
Synset.Example: "He humiliated his colleague by criticising him in front of the boss"
"She was crushed by his refusal of her invitation"
"The death of her son smashed her"

Synset.Definition: reduce in worth or character, usually verbally
Synset.Example: "She tends to put down younger women colleagues"
"His critics took him down after the lecture"

Synset.Definition: lower in grade or rank or force somebody into an undignified situation
Synset.Example: "She reduced her niece to a servant"

Synset.Definition: prove to be of unsound mind or demonstrate someone's incompetence
Synset.Example: "nobody is legally allowed to stultify himself"
"The mayor tried to humanize life in the big city"

Synset.Definition: practice self-denial of one's body and appetites

Synset.Example: "we lamented the death of the child"

Synset.Definition: give verbal or other expression to one's feelings

Synset.Example: "The children teased the boy because of his stammer"

Synset.Definition: to arouse hope, desire, or curiosity without satisfying them
Synset.Example: "The advertisement is intended to tease the customers"
"She has a way of teasing men with her flirtatious behavior"

Synset.Definition: maintain influence over (others or oneself) skillfully, usually to one's advantage
Synset.Example: "She is a very controlling mother and doesn't let her children grow up"
"The teacher knew how to keep the class in line"
"The prize-winning poodle was handled by Mrs. Priscilla Prescott"

Synset.Definition: gain favor with somebody by deliberate efforts
ingratiate oneself to; often with insincere behavior
Synset.Example: "She is playing up to the chairman"
"He warmed to the idea of a trip to Antarctica"

Synset.Definition: be in a huff; be silent or sullen
feel or suffer from the lack of
have a desire for something or someone who is not present
recognize with gratitude; be grateful for
prepare (oneself), often but not necessarily for something unpleasant or difficult
get ready for something difficult or unpleasant
give rise to a desire by being attractive or inviting

Synset.Example: "The idea of a vacation appeals to me"
"The noise and the screaming brought the curious"

Synset.Definition: cause aversion in; offend the moral sense of
cause to feel intense dislike or distaste
be repellent to; cause aversion in
surprise greatly; knock someone's socks off
Synset.Example: "I was floored when I heard that I was promoted"

Synset.Definition: overcome, as with emotions or perceptual stimuli
overwhelm with hilarity, pleasure, or admiration
Synset.Example: "The comedian was so funny, he was killing me!"
"All the guys were knocked out by her charm"

Synset.Definition: astound or overwhelm, as with shock
Synset.Example: "She was staggered with bills after she tried to rebuild her house following the earthquake"
"He was locked in a laughing fit"
"The scandalous behavior of this married woman shocked her friends"

Synset.Definition: abandon hope; give up hope; lose heart
lose confidence or hope; become dejected
Synset.Example: "The supporters of the Presidential candidate desponded when they learned the early results of the election"

Synset.Definition: be optimistic; be full of hope; have hopes
Synset.Example: "I am still hoping that all will turn out well"

Synset.Definition: fill with high spirits; fill with optimism

Synset.Example: "The children were thrilled at the prospect of going to the movies"
"He was inebriated by his phenomenal success"
"The news of her death saddened me"

Synset.Definition: cause to feel extremely joyful or happy
Synset.Example: "the economic growth overjoyed the German industry"
"the conversation lightened me up a bit"
"The bad state of her child's health demoralizes her"

Synset.Definition: give moral or emotional strength to
lessen the intensity of or calm
discharge bad feelings or tension through verbalization
give pleasure to or be pleasing to

Synset.Example: "The waiters around her aim to please"
"A titillating story appeared in the usually conservative magazine"

Synset.Definition: gratify and charm, usually in order to influence

Synset.Example: "Her spirits rose when she heard the good news"

Synset.Definition: inspire with confidence; give hope or courage to

Synset.Example: "The therapist drew out the shy girl"
"The teacher tried to bring out the shy boy"
"The news of the city's surrender chilled the soldiers"

Synset.Definition: deprive of courage or hope; take away hope from; cause to feel discouraged
to compel or deter by or as if by threats
act nervously; be undecided; be uncertain
derive or receive pleasure from; get enjoyment from; take pleasure in
Synset.Example: "She relished her fame and basked in her glory"
"She feasted her eyes on the Tuscan landscape"

Synset.Definition: to render motionless, as with a fixed stare or by arousing terror or awe
excite the curiosity of; engage the interest of
to feel or express sympathy or compassion
express one's sympathetic grief, on the occasion of someone's death
share the feelings of; understand the sentiments of
show no concern or interest; always used in the negative
Synset.Example: "She doesn't give a damn about her job"

Synset.Definition: arouse hostility or indifference in where there had formerly been love, affection, or friendliness
Synset.Example: "She alienated her friends when she became fanatically religious"

Synset.Definition: make withdrawn or isolated or emotionally dissociated

Synset.Example: "The two women, who had been roommates in college, drifted apart after they got married"
"I wish I could go home now"

Synset.Definition: feel or express a desire or hope concerning the future or fortune of
prefer or wish to do something
Synset.Example: "Do you care to try this dish?"
"Would you like to come along to the movies?"

Synset.Definition: be the will of or have the will (to)
Synset.Example: "he could do many things if he pleased"

Synset.Definition: feel or have a desire for; want strongly
have a strong desire or urge to do something
Synset.Example: "She is itching to start the project"

Synset.Definition: have an inclination for something or some activity
Synset.Example: "I feel like staying in bed all day"
"I feel like a cold beer now"
"Some people prefer camping to staying in hotels"
"I trust you will behave better from now on"
"I hope she understands that she cannot expect a raise"

Synset.Definition: be envious of; set one's heart on
wish, long, or crave for (something, especially the property of another person)
be envious, desirous, eager for, or extremely happy about something
Synset.Example: "She was salivating over the raise she anticipated"
"the new neighbor looks down on us because our house is very modest"

Synset.Definition: have a strong sexual desire for
have a liking, fondness, or taste (for)

Synset.Example: "She took great pride in her sons"

Synset.Definition: lose one's emotional or mental composure
Synset.Example: "She fell apart when her only child died"

Synset.Definition: feel strong emotion, especially anger or passion
Synset.Example: "He was burning to try out his new skis"
"She died to worldly things and eventually entered a monastery"
"He was flying high during the summer months"

Synset.Definition: experience a feeling of well-being or happiness, as from good health or an intense emotion

Synset.Example: "Her charm disarmed the prosecution lawyer completely"

Synset.Definition: put into a bad mood or into bad humour
Synset.Example: "The employees were disgruntled by their bad working conditions"

Synset.Definition: frighten or scare, and often provoke into a violent action
be uncertain about; think about without fully understanding or being able to decide
to neither fail to meet nor exceed expectation
Synset.ILIDefinition: to neither fail to meet nor exceed expectation

Synset.Definition: to be a extreme female fan of something
Synset.ILIDefinition: to be a extreme female fan of something
